title: Polynomial Tail Decay for Stationary Measures.pdf
abstract: . We show on complete metric spaces a polynomial tail decay for stationary measures of contracting on average generating measures. Our result applies for example to self-similar or self-aﬃne measures. Contents 1. Introduction 1 2. Proof of Theorem 1.1 and Theorem 1.2 4 3. Further Remarks 7 References 8 1. Introduction Let X be a complete metric space. For a continuous map g : X →X denote by ρ(g) the Lipschitz constant of g deﬁned as ρ(g) = min{ρ > 0 : d(gx, gy) ≤ρ · d(x, y) for all x, y ∈X}, where we use throughout this paper the notation gx = g(x) for all x ∈X. Consider the semi-group L(X) = {g : X →X : ρ(g) < ∞} of Lipschitz maps. For a probability measure µ on L(X) we deﬁne the contraction ratio of µ as χµ = Eg∼µ[log ρ(g)] whenever it exists. Given a further probability measure ν on X the convolution µ ∗ν is the measure uniquely determined by satisfying (µ ∗ν)(f) = Z Z f(gx) dµ(g)dν(x) for all continuous compactly supported functions f : X →R. The main result of this note is the following. We refer to the end of the intro- duction for the asymptotic notation used. Theorem 1.1. Let X be a complete metric space and let µ be a ﬁnitely supported probability measure on L(X) with χµ < 0. Then there exists a unique probability measure ν on X such that µ ∗ν = ν. Moreover, there is α = α(µ) > 0 such that for all x ∈X and R > 0, ν({y ∈X : d(x, y) ≥R}) ≪µ,x R−α, (1.1) where the implied constant depends on µ and x. 1
